BE11:21am

Metro Bank’s 4Q18 preliminary results call has just finished. For us, the key takeways are:
Model adjustments led to £900mn (12%) quarterly increase in RWAs... - this
1.was mainly driven by increases in risk weights for certain commercial loans secured on property and specialist BTL loans to large portfolio landlords.
...which led to a 270bp decrease in CET1 in 4Q: The company didn’t provide a 2.4Q18 figure for its CET1 ratio. Based on the total capital ratio provided (15.8%), assuming unchanged Tier 2 instruments we estimate Metro Bank to have a CET1 ratio of ~13% as of end of 2018. No comments on capital plans: The group provided no comments on its capital
3.plans, saying it will provide an update on the outlook at full year results on February 27.
Earnings miss in the quarter, with underlying PBT for FY18 at £50mn vs.
4.company-compiled consensus at £59mn - the company provided so far only limited detail, indicating that part of the weaker performance was driven by costs related to its branch roll-out. Continued pressure in mortgage pricing: Hasn’t seen any change in pricing
5.conditions during 4Q, with competition in mortgage (e.g. driven by HSBC/ring-fencing) remaining intense.

BE11:23am

Given that we expect the CET1 ratio to fall until at least FY2020E, we now believe that another equity raise is increasingly likely if management adhere to their FY2020E targets. Moreover, 4Q18 underlying PBT of £11.0m compares to our (and consensus) forecast of £18m and underlines that both net interest margin and loan growth is below market expectations with management highlighting an uncertain period for the UK. With Metro Bank trading at FY2018E P/TBV of 1.7x for minimal returns and both the growth and returns targets looking increasingly uncertain we remain Sellers, and reduce our target price to 1,500p (from 2,650p).

The internal review by auditors have suggested that the RWA density for such commercial loans be increased from 50% to 100% and for the BTL portfolios to be increased from 35%t to 100%.
The increased capital allocation throws into question the commerciality of such lending and the impact on growth for Metro bank. Moreover, given the hit to capital and our expectation that the CET1 ratio will continue to fall till FY2020E as the group’s profitability will remain lower than capital consumption, we believe that another equity increase is now more likely this year.

Today's trading update poses more questions than answers - notably on capital planning. We will gain further detail as to the Q4 miss on 27 February (we suspect NIM + 7 store openings the culprit) however the more pressing question is whether management will slow asset growth to offset circa £900m of RWA inflation or if gaining IRB treatment for mortgage exposures in H2 supports capital enough to prevent a change in strategy and prevent further de-rating.

BE11:31am

The online conversation surrounding Metro Bank takes several key forms: 1) consumer complaints specifically made to Metro Bank, 2) consumers complaining to their friends / followers, 3) press surrounding new branch openings, and 4) events or awards that Metro Bank is involved in. The below word cloud highlights the most mentioned words in this conversation, and are either highlighted in red when the sentiment of the conversation when using that word is primarily negative, or green when positive. While naturally words such as “event, “launches”, “open” are talked about positively, these are typically company-lead. Instead, and of concern, is that “Bank”, “Metro”, “Money”, “Card” and “Account”, i.e. words pertaining specifically to the Bank and its services, are talked about in a negative fashion.

- Across the country the majority of sentiment is negative. This is particularly noticeable in Metro’s key market of London. Specifically within London the highest concentration of negativity is within the City, the West End, Shepherd’s Bush, and Wandsworth. We also see some focus in Mayfair, Camden, Beckenham, Lewisham and Bromley.

- We highlight below a selection of negative posts about Metro Bank from January 2019. Much of this highlights a large distrust of the Bank, and general dislike of their customer service. Note that we have also seen an increase in news articles online such as the below, in which a “profoundly deaf woman who lost £8,371 when fraudsters took over her mobile phone and used it to empty her bank account, says her faith in the banking system – and Metro Bank in particular – has been left in tatters”.

- We also flag a number of poor reviews from some of their recent openings such as Bath and Bristol. While this may not be entirely representative (or just reflects teething problems), it could also indicate Metro may find growth tougher outside their ‘core’ footprint of London.

- Either way, all of this is particularly concerning for a bank that seeks to differentiate itself based on ‘retail experience’ and creating ‘fans not customers’. While of course we admit that consumers may always be likely to complain, the key thing to note is the change in perception of Metro Bank. As one of the posts says “Metro Bank is becoming like any other bank, it was only a matter of time, it sucks customers in then stabs them in the back”.

BE11:44am

We believe the best opportunities for 2019 are:
– Buy US heavyside exposure. Margin expansion and resilient infrastructure demand is supportive for Cemex, CRH, Buzzi and Heidelberg.
– Buy cheap lightside self-help stories Saint Gobain and Wienerberger. These names should deliver decent earnings growth despite slower housing trends in Europe.
– Buy UK domestic. Travis Perkins and Forterra look deeply undervalued barring a Brexit crash.
– Avoid US renovation. Leading indicators are concerning for Ferguson.
– Avoid EM cement. We stay cautious on LafargeHolcim and Titan. The market is pricing in upgrades on self-help at LafargeHolcim which we don’t see coming given headwinds especially in Latam and Middle East Africa.
– Avoid insulation names. We stay cautious on Rockwool given margin headwinds but remain neutral on Kingspan, which has less near-term earnings risks and a proven capital allocation strategy.

Accordingly, whilst retaining unchanged estimates, we raise our target price from 720p to 782p – the level of the recommended Apollo offer.

BE11:54am

Could this flush out other prospective buyers? We are doubtful that other prospective buyers are waiting in the wings. Since Bain withdrew from the process in December, there has been no press speculation as to the presence of any other potential bidders. We find it hard to identify likely strategic buyers as many of the peers have elevated financial leverage at this stage of the cycle. We think it unlikely there are many alternative financial/private equity buyers as the scale of RPC makes it too large for many mid-sized private equity firms. The possibility of a bid for RPC has been public since early September 2018 and the absence of any other interest means we think it is unlikely, though clearly not impossible, that others will appear now.

As at the time of writing, SNN shares are off c8%, their lowest level
since Nov-16 and thus, in our view, an opportune entry point for new investors. We attribute most of today’s intraday move to the CEO’s decision to unexpectedly step down. Whilst, at least optically, a strong successor has already been found (Martin Schnaier, previously Sanne’s CCO to take over), management flux at the top of the Group is bound to be viewed unfavorably, especially given SNN only came to market In 2015 and James Ireland (CFO) has been in his post for just over 7 months.
